args: If you cling that closely to me,\nI won't be able to start a fire...
You say that, but you're not exactly\nmaking an effort to get away from me...
That is because I have nothing else\nto keep me warm.
But we're not going to get anywhere if\nwe stay clung together like this.
Right then. Let us count to three,\nthen both pull away at the same time.
*sigh* We finally got a fire started...
These mountain mornings sure are cold,\naren't they?
Yeah. We should make sure to eat\nsomething toasty and warm for breakfast.
A fine plan—but what are we to make?\nAll we have is some of the leftover rice\nwe cooked up yesterday.
Are there any Hinomotoan recipes we\ncould use to turn it into something nice?
Actually, I think I have just the thing.
If we boil some water and make a stock\nfrom yesterday's leftover plants...
Yes! We can make dashi chazuke!\nLemme just do a liiiittle...
So you add dashi broth to the leftover rice,\nlet it soak, and then eat it?
This looks warm and inviting—and\nshould help offset the fact that the rice\nwas nearly burned to a cinder.
Right?! Now let's eat before it gets cold!
The hot dashi is spreading like liquid\nwarmth throughout my frigid body...
I mean, we messed this rice up, right?\nIt's both burned AND undercooked.
Yet we both find it delicious.
Though I suppose the warmth of the dashi\nwouldn't be nearly as impactful were I not\non the verge of freezing to death.
Oh, sorry. I was just remembering\nsomething my dad said.
He said it a lot, actually: ＂The appeal of\nfood isn't just something you experience\nwith your taste buds.＂
＂Who are you eating with?\nWhere are you eating it?\nAnd what did you do to get there?＂
It's about the environment surrounding\nthe food—the experience that leads up to\na meal. THAT'S what changes the appeal!
And it's why he focused on cultivating a\ncertain atmosphere in the restaurant,\nand why we offered exceptional service.
Interesting. Perhaps it is all the twists\nand turns of our recent journey that made\nthis particular breakfast so tasty.
I think so—and I also think this is the\nfirst time I've experienced it for myself.
I mean, I've always known it in theory,\nbut as far back as I can remember,\nI've been caught up in the act of cooking.
I guess I never fully grasped the meaning\nbehind what Dad said—especially after\nhe passed away.
I spent all my time training so I could\nrestore the restaurant, which made me\nlose sight of what it was supposed to BE.
Not exactly the cooking revelation I was\nlooking for, but I think it's pretty important.
Well, I'm glad you were able to take\nsomething good from the experience.
Still, I remain surprised that restaurant\ncooking and outdoor cooking have so\nmuch in common.
Took me a long time to realize it, too.\nGuess I've still got growing to do, huh?
It'll be a long time before I can step into\nDad's shoes for real...
Which is why I want to keep training\nright here in Alberia!
But I want to do it the RIGHT way—\nnot with a bunch of constant worry\nand all-night cooking marathons.
I want to take my time, not rush.\nReally learn from the experience.
That's how I'm going to surpass him.\nI know it.
I look forward to that day—and as the\nmanager of the Halidom's kitchen,\nI will continue to rely on you.
We're gonna make some AMAZING\nmeals together, you and me!
Dear Mitsuba,\nThank you for your letter. We're all happy to hear\nthat you're doing well with your training.

But it's okay—you don't need to rush.
It's true that running Nanakusa is a lot of work,
but all of us here are dedicated to supporting it
until the day you come back home.

PS: Come back home and visit sometime—
and bring your friends from the Halidom!
We'll welcome them with open arms and
give them amazing service to thank them
for all they've done for you.
